title: Improper deep link validation

profile.name: Shopify
profile.about: Shopify is a multi-channel commerce platform that helps people sell online, in-store, and everywhere in between.

vulnerability_information:
The application contains an activity which validates and handles the deep link requests, initiated from a VIEW intent action. The declared schemes include **http** and **https** request for the domain shopify.com as well as \*.myshopify.com. The path prefixes include mostly subdirectories of the /admin path , thus when a deep link request is created the application routes this request to the corresponding activity of the application. 
**It was identified that it is possible to bypass the path prefix restrictions by adding appending a "../" to the end of the URI.  This results on loading arbitrary urls in the application's Webview, leveraging its Javascript capabilities as well as the EASDK bridge in order to compromise the integrity of the application.**
For example in order to access the https://someone.myshopify.com instead of https://someone.myshopify.com/admin/collections in the application's webview, the following intent may be sent: 
```
am start -W -a android.intent.action.VIEW -d "https://ravel17.myshopify.com/admin/collections/../../
```
The above intent will yield the following result: 
{F1172971}

In order to load an external URL the following steps should be followed:
- Create a partner account and add a new app 
- Use as the app's URL the address of the 'malicious' server 

{F1173035}
- Navigate to the "Choose client store" in order to choose the target store

{F1173036}

- Finally, copy the link from the "Merchant install link"

{F1173040}

- Create the following intent:

```
am start -W -a android.intent.action.VIEW -d "https://TARGET-STORE.myshopify.com/admin/collections/.../oauth/install_custom_app?client_id=....
```
- The result will be the following:

{F1173046}

## Impact

As it is mentioned above besides the Javascript which is enabled for the specific webview, the application adds a javascript interface which is accessed via the instantiation of an EASDK object. Some potential risk (besides phishing attacks which may be considered trivial for the specific case) is showed bellow:

- Access to the application's sandbox via the EASDK.redirect:

EASDK.redirect("file:///data/data/com.shopify.mobile/shared_prefs/notification_ids.xml")
{F1173057}

- Javascript code execution:

{F1173073}

activities.message:
Hi @ch0p1n 
thanks for your report. However, someone could just as easily redirect their storefront for anyone visiting it. There does not appear to be any security implications associated with your report. Additionally, phishing and social engineering is out of scope for our program:

> Social Engineering, including phishing

Were you able to leverage this behaviour to access any sensitive information?

> However, someone could just as easily redirect their storefront for anyone visiting it.

The redirection in the specific case refers to the application's webview. **There is no direct way to force the application to load an external website even with the way you mention, someone has to force the loading by exploiting this weakness**, this is why all the deep links received by the app are evaluated and routed to a corresponding activity. If for example a deep link lacks the "/admin/products, /admin/collections,/admin/orders e.t.c. (see manifest) paths, the app won't be even triggered and the link will open in the system's default browser. 

**If running javascript code using the application's context is not considered dangerous, as the webview we are talking about exposes also a javascript bridge, a malicious website may leverage this bridge to perform java calls using the application's context**. One of this calls, as I am showing in the screenshots, is able to fetch data from the application's sandbox, where all the operational data is saved (including sensitive info). TBO, the fact that the bridge is loading local files is also dangerous and should be treated separately as it is a risk for the user (since the application requires access to the sdcard).

>Were you able to leverage this behaviour to access any sensitive information?

Since by leveraging the bridge someone has access to the app's sandbox there is no limit to what can be fetched from there. E.g. by invoking the EASDK.redirect("file:///data/data/com.shopify.mobile/shared_prefs/com.shopify.mobile_preferences.xml"), you have the following:

{F1173785}

Or even export this data leveraging the EASDK.print:

{F1173795}

Another issue that comes up from this behaviour is the fact that the app has access to the external folders:
(EASDK.redirect("file:///sdcard/sensitive.txt"); EASDK.setTitle("shopify's webview"), you have the following:

{F1173799}

Hi @ch0p1n,

We are still looking into this, and will get back to you early next week.
Hello @ch0p1n, Thank you for your report and the additional information! Our team has reproduced the issue and is working on a fix.
Hi Team, any updates on this one ?
HI @michael_hughes , has the severity been determined ?

Hi @ch0p1n,
Thanks again for your report! 
We're awarding a $600 bounty for this issue. Please find below our rationale generated using our [CVSS calculator](https://shopify.github.io/appsec/cvss_calculator/). We have set Attack Complexity to High for this case, as this would require measurable effort to exploit. The most interesting javascript interface exposed to the website is the FilePicker. In order for a merchant to be vulnerable they would need to click a malicious link, the javascript payload would load, and the merchant would need to be tricked into navigating to a sensitive file to share it. This results in a Low Confidentiality impact, as a successful attack would result in disclosure of a single file. 

## Base Score CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N 3.1
## Environment: Core

#### Attack Complexity: H
* Specific conditions or measurable effort to exploit?: Yes

#### Privileges Required: N
* Requires privileged account (not self-registered)?: No

#### User Interaction: R
* Requires victim to perform some action during exploit?: Yes

#### Scope: U
* Can the attacker impact a separate service?: No

#### Confidentiality: L
* How much data could be accessed?: Some
* How much of Shopify is impacted?: Most or All

#### Integrity: N
* How much data could be changed?: None

#### Availability: N
* Level of disruption to network service?: None

Thank you very much team, my only objection is the following:
We had a similar bug with higher severity, according to which the attacker having physical access to the device may sell a shop without authentication.

In the specific case, assuming that the attacker has access to the device, then it may load the javascript payload and trigger the file exposure in order to reveal an authentication token. This information may then be used to log in to the shop from another terminal and perform a CIA bleach. I am not sure I understand the difference. 

>The most interesting javascript interface exposed to the website is the FilePicker. In order for a merchant to be vulnerable they would need to click a malicious link, the javascript payload would load, and the merchant would need to be tricked into navigating to a sensitive file to share it. This results in a Low Confidentiality impact, as a successful attack would result in disclosure of a single file.

Hello @ch0p1n, if the attacker has physical access to the unlocked device then they would not need to perform this exploit to get a token. They would be able to perform whatever actions they would want on the shop as the device is already authenticated. We are considering this attack from the perspective of an attacker phishing the merchant.

@michael_hughes ,

As I was part of #1087382 and  #1082888  which seem to have the same impact (and slightly lower) but different root cause with this one, my question is why this was evaluated differently ?

@ch0p1n, the issues you are referring to bypass a security mechanism that is meant to protect sensitive actions on a shop with a password confirmation. Whereas in this issue, if the attacker were able to exploit this to get the token, they have the same permissions and are able to take the same actions as if they are using the app. Since in your scenario the attacker already has access to the unlocked authenticated device they could simply use the app to perform whichever actions they desired. An attacker with physical access to an unlocked device does not gain any more privileges by using this exploit.

This is why we considered this attack as a merchant being phished by an attacker. Using this attack is may be possible to phish a merchant to share a file with the malicious javascript. Therefore, because this attack requires phishing, the CVSS score has `User Interaction: R` which lowers the bounty amount.

Hey @ch0p1n,
Thanks again for your report! We have shipped a fix for this issue, and you should no longer be able to reproduce this as of 9.7.0. For this reason, we are closing this report as Resolved.

Thank you for hacking on Shopify, and we hope to hear from you again soon!
